title: High Government Investment in Education
description: In 2021, Costa Rica allocated 31.17% of its government expenditure to education, reflecting a strong commitment to educational development.

title: Strong Market Competition Framework
description: Costa Rica achieved an overall market competition score of 68.55 in 2024, with a notable implementation of key services promoting competition at 69.81.

title: Limited Coverage of Unemployment Benefits
description: In 2022, only 19.02% of the population was covered by unemployment benefits and active labor market programs, indicating room for improvement in social safety nets.

title: High Child Employment in Services Sector
description: In 2016, 53.5% of economically active children aged 7-14 were employed in the services sector, with a significant gender disparity favoring females at 79.84%.

title: Gender Disparity in Child Employment
description: In 2016, 45.4% of female children in employment were wage workers, compared to 27.88% of all children, highlighting gender-specific employment trends.

title: High Average Working Hours for Female Children
description: Female children aged 7-14 working only averaged 44.16 hours per week in 2016, indicating a significant burden on young girls in the workforce.

title: Significant Child Employment in Agriculture
description: In 2016, 36.6% of economically active children aged 7-14 in Costa Rica were employed in agriculture, with 20.16% being female. This highlights a significant portion of child labor in the agricultural sector.

title: High Rate of Unpaid Family Work Among Female Children
description: In 2016, 54.59% of female children aged 7-14 in employment were unpaid family workers, indicating a high reliance on unpaid labor within families.

title: Minimal Male Child Employment
description: In 2016, only 1.94% of male children aged 7-14 were employed, reflecting a relatively low rate of child labor among boys in Costa Rica.

title: Negative Net Official Flows from UNWOMEN
description: In 2021, Costa Rica experienced a negative net official flow of -$1,366 from UNWOMEN, indicating a financial outflow rather than support from this agency.
